knowledge.summary: Last In, First Out (LIFO) is a principle that defines the behavior of certain data structures where the last item added is the first one to be removed.
key_points: The stack data structure follows LIFO principle
Items are added and removed from the top of the stack
Commonly used in function calls, undo/redo operations, and recursive function evaluations
knowledge.common_confusion: It's important to remember that while a queue works on First In, First Out (FIFO) principle, a stack operates on LIFO.

knowledge.summary: Push operation adds an element to a stack. It places the new element on top of the existing elements in the stack.
key_points: The added element becomes the topmost element in the stack.
If the stack is empty before the push, it now contains just the new element.
Stack size increases by 1 after pushing an element.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake is to think that the push operation modifies elements at the bottom of the stack instead of adding at the top.

knowledge.summary: The Pop operation removes and returns the top element from a stack in a data structure.
key_points: It reduces the size of the stack by one.
The order of elements is maintained as Last In First Out (LIFO).
The removed element is usually stored temporarily for later use.
knowledge.common_confusion: Some beginners may forget that Pop follows the LIFO principle, so they might expect it to behave like a Queue's Dequeue operation.

knowledge.summary: Peek is an operation in a stack that allows you to view the top element without removing it.
key_points: It provides a way to check the top element of the stack without affecting the order.
The peeked element can still be manipulated by further operations if needed.
However, no changes are made to the stack structure itself.
knowledge.common_confusion: Some beginners may confuse Peek with Pop, as they both involve interacting with the top of the stack. But while Pop removes the top element, Peek only views it.

knowledge.summary: A stack has a limited size or capacity. Once it reaches this limit, additional operations like push or pop cannot be performed until some elements are removed.
key_points: Stack size is defined at the time of creation and cannot be changed during runtime.
Overfilling a stack will result in an error (e.g., 'stack overflow' in programming languages)
A stack can be resized by creating a new one with the desired capacity if needed.
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners may mistakenly believe that a stack always grows or shrinks dynamically to accommodate new elements

knowledge.summary: A stack overflow occurs when the size of a stack exceeds its capacity, leading to an error.
key_points: A stack is a data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle
Each operation adds or removes items from only one end of the stack
If too many operations add items without removing any, the stack may overflow
knowledge.common_confusion: Confusing a stack overflow with an unhandled exception in programming terminology

knowledge.summary: A mathematical structure that defines a set of data and the operations that can be performed on it, without specifying how those operations are implemented.
key_points: It provides a high-level view of the data and the operations that can be performed on it, abstracting away the underlying implementation details
Examples include stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs
Programmers interact with abstract data types through their provided interfaces
knowledge.common_confusion: Abstract data types are not physical objects but rather mathematical constructs used in programming

knowledge.summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
key_points: New items are added to the top of the stack (push operation).
Items can be removed from the top of the stack (pop operation).
The top item on a stack is called the top element.
knowledge.common_confusion: Beginners might confuse stacks with queues, which follow the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.

knowledge.summary: Peek operation in a stack data structure allows you to view the top element without removing it from the stack.
key_points: It provides access to the last element added to the stack without affecting the stack's structure.
The peeked element remains in its position within the stack, preserving the order.
Peeking at an empty stack results in an error as there is no top element.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common mistake is assuming that peeking and popping are the same operations. While both reveal the top element, popping removes it from the stack.

knowledge.summary: Underflow in a stack occurs when an operation is performed to remove an element, but the stack is already empty.
key_points: It is caused by inserting elements into an empty stack and then repeatedly popping them without reinserting any new elements.
This situation can lead to unexpected behavior as popping an empty stack results in an error.
To avoid underflow, always ensure there are elements in the stack before performing a pop operation.
knowledge.common_confusion: A common beginner mistake is assuming that simply inserting elements into a stack will prevent underflow, but forgetting to reinsert elements after popping can still result in this pitfall.

knowledge.summary: Determines whether a stack is devoid of elements.
key_points: A common method to check if a stack is empty is by using the 'is_empty' or 'isEmpty' function provided by programming languages.
This function typically returns true when the stack has no elements and false otherwise.
It's crucial to perform this check before performing operations that might result in an error (like popping from an empty stack)
knowledge.common_confusion: New programmers sometimes forget to include this check, leading to runtime errors.

knowledge.summary: The stack size refers to the total amount of memory allocated for a specific call stack. It determines how many function calls can be active concurrently before an error occurs.
key_points: Each function call adds to the stack, consuming memory.
Exceeding the stack size leads to a stack overflow error.
The stack size is configurable in some programming languages and environments.
knowledge.common_confusion: It's often confused with the total memory a program can use, but it specifically pertains to call stacks.

knowledge.summary: Implementing a stack in an array involves using an array as the underlying container and following rules to maintain the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle. In a linked list implementation, nodes are connected using pointers to achieve the same.
key_points: Array implementation uses the concept of top index which keeps track of the top element.
Linked List implementation uses nodes with next and prev pointers to manage the stack.
Both methods allow push, pop, peek operations for efficient handling of the stack.
knowledge.common_confusion: Forgetting to update the top index or pointer when performing push/pop operations may lead to incorrect stack behavior.
